title: How to Play MP3 Files on a PlayStation 3

parts.name: Find Out If Your File Is An MP3

steps.headline: Open up the file where your music file is located.
steps.description:
This may be anywhere on your computer. On most computers it will be in your User's Music folder. To access this:
Click on the File Explorer on the bottom left-hand side of the screen. You'll notice under your name (Mitchell) in the left column of the box you'll find a folder named Music. If you downloaded the music from the internet, it may be in your Downloads folder. In that same left column near the top you will see Downloads. Click that and search for it in there. If it isn't in there you'll have to do some searching to find out where it is.

steps.headline: Hover your mouse over the file.
steps.description: Once you put the mouse over the file, it should give you a small dialog box. The first line of that box should say "Item type:" If it says "MP3 Format Sound" then you have an MP3 file. If not, then you'll have to find an MP3 file. If you have none, then look up how to convert the file to an MP3.

steps.headline: If the dialog box doesn't show up, go to the file properties.
steps.description: Right click the file. A box should come up with many different options. Look at the bottom of the box and click the properties button. This will bring up another box with different information, such as the file type, size of the file, and so on.

steps.headline: Look at the "Type of File" line.
steps.description: This line should say "MP3 Format Sound", followed by the extension of the file (.mp3). If it does, all is good. If not, go back to searching and repeat the steps in this Part until you have done so.

parts.name: Put MP3 Files Onto Flash Drive

steps.headline: Plug the flash drive into computer.
steps.description: Open up the file of the USB.

steps.headline: Open the file explorer.
steps.description: Once you plug the flash drive into an open USB slot on your computer, open up your computer's file explorer. On the left-hand side underneath the section that is labeled as the name of your computer, seen as "Mitchell" in the photo below, click the name of the flash drive you just put in. The example one is labeled "FLASHDRIVE".

steps.headline: Create a sub-folder inside the folder of the USB.
steps.description: After you've opened up the folder for the USB, go ahead and create another folder and name it anything you want. To do so, right click in the window, hover over "New" and then click "Folder". Proceed to type in the name of what you want to call it. This is more to keep everything inside the flash drive organized than anything else.

steps.headline: Drag and drop the MP3 files into the flash drive.
steps.description: Open up the folder where the MP3 files are. Highlight the files you want to transfer, then drag and drop them into the folder in your flash drive.

steps.headline: Eject the flash drive.
steps.description: To prevent corruption, right click the name of your flash drive in the left column. Once the box opens up, find "Eject" and click it to safely eject your flash drive.

steps.headline: Insert the flash drive into the USB.
steps.description: Turn on the PS3. On the front left of the console there are two slots that allow USB's to be inserted into them. Put your flash drive into one of them. After doing that, press the power button on the right-hand side of the console.

steps.headline: Under the music heading, find the flash drive that you just plugged in.
steps.description: Go under the music section of the XrossMediaBar, or the horizontal headings, and scroll down until you see the name of the flash drive that was plugged in moments before.

steps.headline: Press the X button, then choose an MP3 file.
steps.description: You will notice all the music that you put onto the flash drive shows up in this folder. Go ahead and choose any song you want and press the X button on your controller once you have done so. Your music should now be playing.

steps.headline: If you experience trouble transferring the files to the flash drive:
steps.description: It's possible your flash drive may not be big enough in size. You can't put 3 Gigabytes (GB) of music onto a 2GB flash drive. Try using a flash drive with a bigger capacity.

steps.headline: If you find that the files fail to show up once you press the X button on the flash drive:
steps.description: Press the Circle button to go back and then press the Triangle button. After that, hit X to press "Display All". Your files should show up now.

text:
Find Out If Your File Is An MP3 Open up the file where your music file is located. This may be anywhere on your computer. On most computers it will be in your User's Music folder. To access this:
Click on the File Explorer on the bottom left-hand side of the screen. You'll notice under your name (Mitchell) in the left column of the box you'll find a folder named Music. If you downloaded the music from the internet, it may be in your Downloads folder. In that same left column near the top you will see Downloads. Click that and search for it in there. If it isn't in there you'll have to do some searching to find out where it is. Hover your mouse over the file. Once you put the mouse over the file, it should give you a small dialog box. The first line of that box should say "Item type:" If it says "MP3 Format Sound" then you have an MP3 file. If not, then you'll have to find an MP3 file. If you have none, then look up how to convert the file to an MP3. If the dialog box doesn't show up, go to the file properties. Right click the file. A box should come up with many different options. Look at the bottom of the box and click the properties button. This will bring up another box with different information, such as the file type, size of the file, and so on. Look at the "Type of File" line. This line should say "MP3 Format Sound", followed by the extension of the file (.mp3). If it does, all is good. If not, go back to searching and repeat the steps in this Part until you have done so. Put MP3 Files Onto Flash Drive Plug the flash drive into computer. Open up the file of the USB. Open the file explorer. Once you plug the flash drive into an open USB slot on your computer, open up your computer's file explorer. On the left-hand side underneath the section that is labeled as the name of your computer, seen as "Mitchell" in the photo below, click the name of the flash drive you just put in. The example one is labeled "FLASHDRIVE". Create a sub-folder inside the folder of the USB. After you've opened up the folder for the USB, go ahead and create another folder and name it anything you want. To do so, right click in the window, hover over "New" and then click "Folder". Proceed to type in the name of what you want to call it. This is more to keep everything inside the flash drive organized than anything else. Drag and drop the MP3 files into the flash drive. Open up the folder where the MP3 files are. Highlight the files you want to transfer, then drag and drop them into the folder in your flash drive. Eject the flash drive. To prevent corruption, right click the name of your flash drive in the left column. Once the box opens up, find "Eject" and click it to safely eject your flash drive. Play Files on PS3 Insert the flash drive into the USB. Turn on the PS3. On the front left of the console there are two slots that allow USB's to be inserted into them. Put your flash drive into one of them. After doing that, press the power button on the right-hand side of the console. Under the music heading, find the flash drive that you just plugged in. Go under the music section of the XrossMediaBar, or the horizontal headings, and scroll down until you see the name of the flash drive that was plugged in moments before. Press the X button, then choose an MP3 file. You will notice all the music that you put onto the flash drive shows up in this folder. Go ahead and choose any song you want and press the X button on your controller once you have done so. Your music should now be playing. Troubleshooting If you experience trouble transferring the files to the flash drive: It's possible your flash drive may not be big enough in size. You can't put 3 Gigabytes (GB) of music onto a 2GB flash drive. Try using a flash drive with a bigger capacity. If you find that the files fail to show up once you press the X button on the flash drive: Press the Circle button to go back and then press the Triangle button. After that, hit X to press "Display All". Your files should show up now.
